facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 51 and 53 of 1965 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 51 and 53 of 1965. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of the Fundamental Rights. C.

facts.text: Petitioners are members of the Left Communist Party.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are members of the Left Communist Party and were ordered to be detained along with others numbering 140 in all under r. 30 1   b

facts.text: Petitioners ordered to be detained along with 140 others under r. 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules by Governor of Kerala on December 29, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are members of the Left Communist Party and were ordered to be detained along with others numbering 140 in all under r. 30 1   b  of the Defence of India Rules  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  by orders of the Governor of Kerala passed on December 29, 1964.

facts.text: Petitioners arrested on December 30, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of these orders the petitioners were arrested on December 30, 1964. At that time the State of Kerala was being governed by virtue of the Proclamation of the President dated September 10, 1964.

facts.text: State of Kerala governed by President's Proclamation dated September 10, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of these orders the petitioners were arrested on December 30, 1964. At that time the State of Kerala was being governed by virtue of the Proclamation of the President dated September 10, 1964. By this Proclamation the President assumed to himself all functions of the Government  1

facts.text: President assumed all functions of Government of Kerala, powers of Governor, legislature by Parliament via Proclamation.

anchor.surface_text: By this Proclamation the President assumed to himself all functions of the Government  1  1966 2 S.C.R. 178. of the State of Kerala and all powers vested in or exercisable by the Governor of that State and declared that the powers of the legislature of the said State would be exercisable by or under the authority of Parliament.

facts.text: President to act through Governor of Kerala to such extent as thought fit.

anchor.surface_text: The Proclamation also provided that in the exercise of the functions and powers assumed by the President with respect to the governance of the State, the President would act to such extent as he thought fit through the Governor of the said State.

facts.text: Petitioners claim detention orders of December 29, 1964 were mala fide to damage Left Communist Party prospects in general election beginning March 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioners is that these orders of detention were mala fide inasmuch as a general election was going to be hold in Kerala in the beginning of March 1965. In order to damage the prospects of the Left Communist Party in the election and to improve that of the Congress Party these orders of detention were made under the Rules.

facts.text: General election in Kerala beginning of March 1965.

anchor.surface_text: mala fide inasmuch as a general election was going to be hold in Kerala in the beginning of March 1965.

facts.text: After elections, Left Communist Party emerged as largest single party.

anchor.surface_text: After the elections were over, the Left Communist Party emerged as the largest single party.

facts.text: Order of Governor dated December 29, 1964 cancelled on March 4, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently it is said that on March 4. 1965, the order of the Governor dated December 29, 1964 was cancelled and another order was made on the same date  namely, March 4, 1965  by the Central Government in the name of the President ordering the detention of the petitioners under the Rules.

facts.text: New detention order made on March 4, 1965 by Central Government in name of President under the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: namely, March 4, 1965  by the Central Government in the name of the President ordering the detention of the petitioners under the Rules. The petitioners companytend that this order was also mala fide as it was made to circumvent the possibility of the Petitioners release in case a party-government came into power in the State of Kerala after the elections.

facts.text: Petitioners claim March 4, 1965 order mala fide to circumvent possible release after elections.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companytend that this order was also mala fide as it was made to circumvent the possibility of the Petitioners release in case a party-government came into power in the State of Kerala after the elections.

facts.text: Cancellation order and new detention order both served on petitioners on March 6, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It is further urged that the order of cancellation was passed on March 4, 1965 and so was the new order of detention but both these orders were served on them on March 6, 1965.

facts.text: Replies filed on behalf of Government of India denying allegations re March 4, 1965 detention.

anchor.surface_text: Replies have been filed on behalf of the Government of India traversing all the allegations so far as detention under the order dated March 4, 1965 is companycerned.

facts.text: No reply filed by Governor of Kerala as State not party to petitions.

anchor.surface_text: No reply has been filed on behalf of the Governor of Kerala with respect to the detention order of December 29, 1964 for the reason that the State, of Kerala was number made a party to these petitions.

facts.text: Petitions made to jail authorities on March 15, 1965, reached Supreme Court on April 12, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Before we leave these cases we would like to refer to the inordinate delay that took place between the making of the petitions to the jail authorities and their reaching this Court. The petitions were made on March 15, 1965 but they reached this Court on April 12, 1965, exactly four weeks later.

facts.text: Petitioners claim no application of mind in passing detention orders on Dec 29, 1964 and March 4, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners further companytend that there was numberapplication of the mind of the authority when the orders of detention were passed on December 29, 1964 and March 4, 1965.

facts.text: Petitioners claim no material before Central Government on March 4, 1965 for detention orders.

anchor.surface_text: Further it is companytended that there was numbermaterial before the Central Government on March 4, 1965 on the basis of which the orders of detention companyld be passed and therefore the orders passed on that date were illegal.

facts.text: Government of India states materials placed before it satisfied necessity to detain on March 4, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It has been clearly stated on behalf of the Government of India that on the materials placed before it is was so satisfied before it passed the orders dated March 4, 1965.

facts.text: Court holds detention under March 4, 1965 orders legal.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to see is whether the detention under the fresh order passed on March 4, 1965 was legal when the petition for habeas companypus was made. As to that we have numberdoubt that it is legal.

facts.text: Court rejects contention that 140 orders on same day shows no application of mind.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is numberforce in this companyvention either. The reply on behalf of Government of India in this companynection is that the question as to the detention, of the persons who were ordered to be detained on March 4, 1965 was under companysideration of the Government of India.

facts.text: Government of India had files on activities of petitioners before passing March 4 orders.

anchor.surface_text: The reply of the Government of India is that the file pertaining to the activities of the petitioners and others like them and the material relating thereto were before the Government of India when the orders of March 4, 1965 were passed.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed by court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore dismiss the petitions.

Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of the Fundamental Rights. C. Chatterjee, M. R. K. Pillai, M. S. K. Aiyangar, D. Singh, R. K. Garg, S. C. Agarwala, M. K. Ramamurthi, for the petitioner  in W.P. No. 51 .

These two petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution for a writ of habeas corpus raise common questions and will be dealt with together. The main points raised in these petitions have been dealt with in K. Ananda Nambiar v. Chief Secretary, Government of Madras and others 1  in which judgment is being delivered today.

arguments.claim: In habeas corpus petition, court examines only legality of detention on date of application to court

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that in dealing with a petition for habeas corpus the court has to see whether the detention on the date on which the application is made to the court is legal, if nothing more has intervened between the date of the application and the .date of hearing.

arguments.claim: March 4, 1965 orders not mala fide as Central Government satisfied of necessity under Rule 30(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: But apart form this denial we fail to see how the orders passed on March 4, 1965 can be said to be mala fide if the Central Government was satisfied that with a view to preventing the petitioners from acting in a manner prejudicial to the defence of India, civil defence, public safety and public order it was necessary to detain them.

arguments.claim: Governor's December 29, 1964 orders were effectively President's orders under Proclamation; cancellation valid

anchor.surface_text: We have already indicated that when the orders of December 29, 1964 were passed the President had assumed all functions of Government of the State of Kerala and the Governor was the agent of the President in the matter of governance of the State to such extent as the President thought fit to act through him.

arguments.claim: No need for physical release and re-arrest when cancelling prior orders and issuing fresh ones on same day

anchor.surface_text: It was not necessary to carry out the empty formality of release from jail under the orders of cancellation and then to arrest the persons released immediately they came out of jail and to serve on them the new order of detention dated March 4, 1965  see Smt. Godavari Shamrao Parulekar v. The State of Maharashtra

arguments.claim: Detention under March 4, 1965 fresh orders is legal

anchor.surface_text: What we have to see is whether the detention under the fresh order passed on March 4, 1965 was legal when the petition for habeas corpus was made. As to that we have no doubt that it is legal.

holdings.text: It is well-settled that in dealing with a petition for habeas corpus the court has to see whether the detention on the date on which the application is made to the court is legal, if nothing more has intervened between the date of the application and the date of hearing.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that in dealing with a petition for habeas corpus the court has to see whether the detention on the date on which the application is made to the court is legal, if nothing more has intervened between the date of the application and the .date of hearing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent establishes scope of habeas corpus inquiry limited to legality of current detention; prior cancelled orders irrelevant.

holdings.text: The orders passed on March 4, 1965 were not mala fide even if there was a possibility of release by a new state government.

anchor.surface_text: But apart form this denial we fail to see how the orders passed on March 4, 1965 can be said to be mala fide if the Central Government was satisfied that with a view to preventing the petitioners from acting in a manner prejudicial to the defence of India, civil defence, public safety and public order it was necessary to detain them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government's affidavit affirms subjective satisfaction on materials for necessity under Rule 30(1)(b); mere anticipation of release does not prove bad faith.

holdings.text: There is no force in the contention that there was no application of mind by the Government of India before passing the 140 orders on March 4, 1965; this contention must also fail.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in this contention either. The reply on behalf of Government of India in this connection is that the question as to the detention, of the persons who were ordered to be detained on March 4, 1965 was under consideration of the Government of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit states cases under consideration for some time with individual satisfaction; simultaneity of orders does not negate application of mind.

holdings.text: There is no force in the contention that there was no material before the Central Government before it passed the orders on March 4, 1965 and it is hereby rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The reply of the Government of India is that the file pertaining to the activities of the petitioners and others like them and the material relating thereto were before the Government of India when the orders of March 4, 1965 were passed. We fail to see why there could not be two, files relating to the activities of the petitioners one with the Government of Kerala and another with the Government of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government affidavit asserts relevant files and materials were before it; court accepts possibility of multiple files and credibility of affidavit.

holdings.text: The order of the Governor dated December 29, 1964 was in the circumstances the order of the President acting through the agency of the Governor and it was open to the President to cancel the order passed by his agent; the cancellation cannot be assailed as illegal.

anchor.surface_text: We have already indicated that when the orders of December 29, 1964 were passed the President had assumed all functions of Government of the State of Kerala and the Governor was the agent of the President in the matter of governance of the State to such extent as the President thought fit to act through him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under President's Proclamation, Governor acted as President's agent; thus Governor's detention order was President's, enabling cancellation by President.

holdings.text: There was nothing illegal in the President withdrawing the orders of detention of December 29, 1964 and thereafter the Central Government passing the orders of detention of its own on the same day.

anchor.surface_text: These orders were passed when the Government of the State of Kerala was being carried on under the Proclamation of September 10, 1964. That did not prevent the Central Government from deciding whether it should itself detain these persons who had till then been detained under the orders of December 29, 1964.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Central Government could replace state-level detention with its own under Proclamation; no illegality even absent state agreement in this context.

holdings.text: It was not necessary to carry out the empty formality of release from jail under the orders of cancellation and then to arrest the persons released immediately they came out of jail and to serve on them the new order of detention dated March 4, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It was not necessary to carry out the empty formality of release from jail under the orders of cancellation and then to arrest the persons released immediately they came out of jail and to serve on them the new order of detention dated March 4, 1965  see Smt. Godavari Shamrao Parulekar v. The State of Maharashtra

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent supports validity of successive detention orders without physical release and re-arrest when replacing one valid order with another.

holdings.text: The detention under the fresh order passed on March 4, 1965 was legal when the petition for habeas corpus was made; as to that we have no doubt that it is legal.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to see is whether the detention under the fresh order passed on March 4, 1965 was legal when the petition for habeas corpus was made. As to that we have no doubt that it is legal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges to March 4 orders rejected; satisfies habeas corpus test of current legality under Rule 30(1)(b).

edges.explanation: The holding restates and affirms the precise legal principle at issue regarding the scope of court inquiry in habeas corpus petitions, confirming that only the legality of detention on the date of application to the court needs to be examined.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that in dealing with a petition for habeas corpus the court has to see whether the detention on the date on which the application is made to the court is legal, if nothing more has intervened between the date of the application and the .date of hearing.
We therefore dismiss the petitions.

anchor.surface_text: But apart form this denial we fail to see how the orders passed on March 4, 1965 can be said to be mala fide if the Central Government was satisfied that with a view to preventing the petitioners from acting in a manner prejudicial to the defence of India, civil defence, public safety and public order it was necessary to detain them.
We therefore dismiss the petitions.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in this contention either. The reply on behalf of Government of India in this connection is that the question as to the detention, of the persons who were ordered to be detained on March 4, 1965 was under consideration of the Government of India.
We therefore dismiss the petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The reply of the Government of India is that the file pertaining to the activities of the petitioners and others like them and the material relating thereto were before the Government of India when the orders of March 4, 1965 were passed. We fail to see why there could not be two, files relating to the activities of the petitioners one with the Government of Kerala and another with the Government of India.
We therefore dismiss the petitions.

anchor.surface_text: We have already indicated that when the orders of December 29, 1964 were passed the President had assumed all functions of Government of the State of Kerala and the Governor was the agent of the President in the matter of governance of the State to such extent as the President thought fit to act through him.
We therefore dismiss the petitions.
